title: Red Rock Fury
text:
Perched in the desert, proud and absurd,
A sandstone cliff — an Angry Bird.
Its beak juts sharp, its brow is stern,
As if awaiting its turn to burn.
The wind plays slingshot, the clouds take aim,
But this rock just chuckles, immune to the game.
Forever frozen in feathery guise,
A grumpy guardian under bluebird skies.
Lizards parade by its scowling face,
Whispering tales of its lofty place.
Tourists snap photos, delighted to find,
A relic of pixels in stone redefined.
And when twilight paints the canyon red,
The Angry Bird will live on in your head —
A game once played on a glowing screen,
Now etched by time in a desert scene.

title: Guardian of the Canyon Wall
text:
If you wander where the waters run,
Past sandstone cliffs in the desert sun,
You’ll find a beast both strange and sly,
With wooden jaws that snap the sky.
Its tail is curled beneath itself,
A driftwood gator perched on the shelf.
Or maybe some old canyon sprite,
Who guards the Inner Flume by day and night.
Hikers stop with wide-eyed cheer:
“Look! A dragon’s waiting here!”
Carved by flood and nature’s play,
It roars only to scare the dust away.
So if you roam above the Flume’s embrace,
And stumble on this creature’s place,
Just wave and laugh, don’t be afraid —
The canyon’s myths are all homemade!

title: The Dapper Duck of Fruita
text:
Near Fruita stands a rock so odd,
A sandstone duck that gives a nod.
With fancy hat perched on its head,
It looks like royalty instead!
This stony fowl with fashion sense
Makes tourists stop in pure suspense.
“Is that a duck wearing a hat?”
“Or am I stoned?” (It might be that!)
The Colorado winds may blow,
But duckie’s hat won’t ever go.
While other ducks must swim and fly,
This one just winks at passers-by.

title: Sandstone Sonnets
text: On this page you’ll find poems written about natural features in and around Fruita. These are a bit like a scavenger hunt - see if you can figure out what features these poems describe.

All
Devil’s Canyon
Flume Canyon

title: The Canyon’s Secret Grin
text:
If you search the canyon wall,
A cheeky smile grins down at all.
Red rock carved by wind and time,
Sharing nature’s favorite rhyme.
Green trees giggle from above,
Junipers whisper tales of love.
While hikers stop and point with glee:
“Look! The canyon’s smiling at me!”
This sandstone jester never frowns,
Just grins at all the desert towns.
A million-year-old happy face,
That makes D4 such a lovely place!
So if you’re walking Fruita’s trails
And need a laugh when courage fails,
Just look up at that crimson wall—
The canyon’s smiling after all!

HintsAnswer








TipHint #1: Umm…what am I looking for?





There is a place somewhere on the D4 trail where it looks like a big smile was carved into the sandstone.









TipHint #2: In what general area should I look?





This feature is located on the loop section of D4.









TipHint #3: Ok, I need a photo please.





INSERT IMAGE.

title: The Desert Shipwreck
text:
If you wander where the cliffs stand high,
A breaching whale will catch your eye.
Its sandstone flukes once crashed the sea,
And wrecked a ship for all to see.
The vessel lingered, ghostly drawn,
Its sails were torn, its crew long gone.
Yet its ghostly shell still remains,
A sandstone hull upon the plain.
The whale looks proud, a trickster bold,
A million years of tales retold.
While desert winds still sing a song:
The whale’s been laughing all along.
So if you stroll these rugged lands,
With dust and wonder in your hands,
Look close — the tale is clear:
A whale sunk that ship right here!

title: Patina Portrait
text:
Look across the canyon face,
A weathered man holds his place.
With hair of brown and moustache too,
A coat of varnish, earthen hue.
No brush has touched this rocky wall,
Yet nature’s paint outshines them all.
A portrait formed in desert glaze,
Was he a sheriff? Merchant? Who’s to say?
His eyes are gone, worn smooth by time,
Yet still he keeps a watch sublime.
Flume canyon rests beneath his gaze,
An old prospector from those bygone days?
So give a nod as you pass on by,
This stoic stranger won’t reply.
But desert varnish keeps him near,
A patinaed figure from yesteryear.
